column4: i suggest to write a litte script that ouputs such using netstat
i'm no hacker. i'm a newb
where do you want to use it for? maybe there are other solutions?
you can view a list of used ports with something like "netstat -atun". port numbers for tcp and udp reach from 0 to 65535, so everything not mentioned is unused atm
is there a netstat command to get a list of UNused ports?
that list normally would be quite long and confusing
here's netstat -atun printout: http://pastebin.com/m6cbf46e7 . what is a low number for unused port?
what column are you looking at to find ports?
the column "local address". 1 is not a good choice. choose some port > 1023, that does not show up after the ':' in the local address column
choose a port > 1023. if this is for port forwarding, also make sure, that no firewall an the target computer is blocking the port there
i have no firewall on my comp
you can try a sniffer to watch, what packets arrive at the computer: sudo tcpdump -n -i eth0 'port 1099'
i did your command and all i got was the "greater than" [ >  ] symbol
so far... "tcpdump: verbose output suppressed, use -v or -vv for full protocol decode listening on eth0, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet), capture size 96 bytes"

that sounds good. it listens and will print a line for each packet matching the expression in the '' (here packets with port 1099 anywhere). with that and some variantions you should be able to experiment and maybe get it working. i have no time left, sorry... bye
but you should consider to read something about tcp/ip networking, routing, nat and firewalling
